intro: Eugenioides hebanthum, commonly known as the velvetwood or wild coffee, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa and Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 14,000 species, many of which are economically important. The plant is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves and produces small, clustered white flowers that are often followed by red or orange berries. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in rainforests or undergrowth. The plant has been used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties.
